Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Hudson River Undergraduate Mathematics Conference 2018" that will be held on April 7, 2018 at the Saint Lawrence University in Canton, New York.

The purpose of the conference is to motivate undergraduate students to consider careers and further study in the field of mathematics. The structure of the conference is such that students will be able to network with peers and faculty, as well as to listen to a lecture from an esteemed mathematician, as to the opportunities and life style afforded mathematical science majors, and to give students an opportunity to present the results of their research. A strong effort will be made to invite students who are members of underrepresented groups, first generation college students, and women. More information will be made available at:

POR.DRECONTENT:
On April 7, 2018, St. Lawrence University in Canton, NY hosted the 25th Annual Hudson River Undergraduate Mathematics Conference (HRUMC).  There were 158 registered attendees. This HRUMC was made possible by generous support from the National Science Foundation, DMS 1807502, as well as the Mathematics, Computer Science and Statistics Department at St. Lawrence University.  The keynote speaker for the conference was Karen Saxe of Macalester College and the American Mathematical Society who talked on “Mathematics and Social Justice”. This year as in the past, the conference provided significant opportunities for undergraduate students to attend a professional conference and present their work, to learn about a diverse range of topics in the mathematical sciences, and to interact with students and faculty with similar interests from other academic institutions.  Below we discuss the outcomes of this conference.

 

The intellectual merit of this grant is that it funded four innovations to HRUMC, a regional undergraduate mathematics conference that was attended by 158 people who travelled a median distance of 150 miles to attend the conference.  The first innovation at this conference was a series of presentations on further opportunities in the mathematical sciences. These presentations were entitled “Identifying Internship & Research Opportunities”, “Getting Into Graduate Study” and “Career Options and Job Search Strategies”.  Each of the presentations designed and executed by St. Lawrence University’s Career Services Office was run three times, once is each set of speaking sessions, so that all students would have an opportunity to attend these valuable sessions. Second, to further provide students with information about careers in the mathematical sciences, the conference added two panels about the experiences of recent graduates: one on experiences in graduate school and one on experiences in industry.  A post conference survey about attendee experiences was the third innovation for HRUMC and there was an 80% response rate for this survey. The survey instrument and summaries of the responses will be made publicly available and may form a baseline for assessing the impact of future undergraduate mathematics conferences. The fourth innovation that was completed as part of the 2018 HRUMC was the expansion of outreach to underrepresented groups and women to encourage attendance.

 

The broader impact of this grant were threefold.  First, the conference provided an opportunity for students to present their own scholarship in mathematics as well as networking with other students.   The vast majority of the attendees, 77%, were students. Second, the conference provided presentation and networking opportunities for all attendees. Sixty-five presentations were made and the vast majority of those were by students.  Further, this was the first mathematics conference for about 46% of the attendees according to the post-conference survey. Additionally, for the first time at the conference we ran panels on working in industry, and on going to graduate school aimed at students.  Among the students who attended these panels, 70% had a “positive” or “life changing in a positive way” view of the panels, while only 1 of 109 student respondents to this question had a “negative” view of the panels. Third, we added a panel discussion concerning the mentoring of undergraduate research in mathematics which is novel for HRUMC.  The vast majority of faculty, 18 of 21, who responded to the post-conference survey found it to be a positive experience. Finally, we were able to attract a diverse set of attendees. Forty-eight percent of the attendees were female and 18% of the attendees were non-Caucasian based upon the post-conference survey.

 

Some additional highlights from the post-conference survey.

  • The response rate for the survey was 81%
  • Attendance among students was 53% female and 23% non-Caucasian.
  • Among the student respondents, 45 (of 96) or 47%  said that attending HRUMC has influenced their decision to follow a career in the mathematical sciences.
  • About 55% — 53 of 96 — of the student respondents considered HRUMC a ‘vital element’ of their undergraduate mathematical experience.
  • Students and faculty travelled an average of 150 miles to attend the conference.
  • Approximately 35% of those students stated that they ‘Agree’ or ‘Strongly Agree’ that the conference has influenced their decision to pursue graduate school or advanced study in the mathematical sciences.
  • Overall 92% of attendees rated their experience at HRUMC as ‘Life changing in a positive way’ or ‘Positive’. These rates were 91% for students and 96% for faculty.
